oreo_pegasus_output: In March 2017, a class-action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington on behalf of children held in solitary confinement at King County's Maleng Regional Justice Center (RJC) and the King COLUMBIA LEGAL SERVICES Institutions Project 1 County Jail. The plaintiffs alleged that King County’s policy of holding children in isolation cells for weeks and months on end violated their constitutional rights and denied them an adequate education. The court approved a settlement between the plaintiffs and King County and the Kent School District. Under the terms of the settlement, Plaintiffs will receive $240,000 from King 8 County, less $25,000 in attorney fees, to be evenly apportioned amongst Plaintiffs, and $25,000 9 from the Kent school district. The case has not been certified as a class action.
pegasus_output: In March 2017, a group of children charged as adults in King County filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against King County, the Kent School District, and the King County Sheriff's Office. The plaintiffs alleged that King County had violated the children's civil rights by keeping them in isolation for long-term periods of time, denying them adequate education, and failing to provide them with appropriate housing options and programming opportunities. The case was settled in August 2018. The parties agreed to a settlement in September 2018. The case is closed.

gold: On April 3, 2008, Muslim prisoners sued the Wyoming Department of Corrections for violations of First Amendment Rights and the RLUIPA for failure to accommodate their religious practices.  The case was resolved by Consent Decree on November 19, 2008.
source:
Civ No. 08-CV-090B PLAINTIFFS' MOTION FOR PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION, AND BRIEF IN SUPPORT INTRODUCTION Plaintiffs Joseph Miller and Hurie Purdiman, Jr., are Muslim prisoners incarcerated in the Wyoming State Penitentiary ("WSP"). They file this motion in an effort to immediately halt further violations of rights guaranteed them by the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act of 2000 ("RLUIPA"), 114 Stat. 804, 42 U.S.C. § 2000cc.

Defendant Michael Murphy is the Warden of WSP, and Defendant Robert Lampert is the Director of the Wyoming Department of Corrections ("WDOC"). These prison officials adopted, and their subordinates at WSP enforce, a policy known as the "twenty-minute" rule. This policy requires segregated prisoners to eat their meals within twenty minutes after delivery by guards.
For reasons set forth in their Declarations, Plaintiffs pray five times each day and periodically engage in religious fasts from sunup until sundown. In addition, they receive special religious ("Halal") meals from WSP due to their religious dietary constraints. Defendant Michael Murphy is the Warden of WSP.
Prison officials refused to offer other types of Halal food that were readily available and medically palatable to Mr Shakur. The district court granted summary judgment to prison officials on Mr. Shakur's RLUIPA claim, but the Ninth Circuit reversed. Prison officials were giving Mr. Shakur a "Hobson's choice" that violated RLUIPA, requiring him to choose between eating and remaining faithful to his religious beliefs.
Plaintiffs are under the care custody and control of the named defendants, Micha el Murphy, Wa rden of WSP, and Robert Lampe rt, Director of the Wyomi ng Department of Correction s. Plaintiffs filed this action seeking relief under the First Amendment to the U.S. Constitution and under the Reli gio us Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act 42 U.S.c. §§ 2000cc et seq. (RLUl PA). Plaintiffs devote certain times each day to prayer, and certain days each year to fasting.
The Court commends the parties for reaching a reasonable result that accommodates Plaintiffs' religious exercises while not unduly threatening the needs of prison officials to maintain order and security. Dated this fY'!:. day of MW!h t"cR1.
In a word, RLUIPA is designed to ensure that prisoners have a right to engage in certain religious exercises, even if is inconvenient for prison officials to accommodate that right, unless prison officials have a compelling need to suppress these religious activities. The two named Plaintiffs in this lawsuit are Muslims incarcerated in the Wyoming State Penitentiary. As a matter of faith, Plaintiffs devote specific time each day to prayer, and certain days of each year to fasting.
As a result of the prison policy challenged herein, Plaintiffs must choose between adhering to their deeply held religious beliefs and eating meals. Defendants' policy requires prisoners to eat their meals within twenty minutes after delivery, after which the meals are confiscated. Plaintiffs have requested of Defendants that they be exempted from this rule when a religious exercise, such as prayer or fasting, renders consuming the meal within twenty minutes impracticable, but Defendants have denied these requests.
PARTIES 2. Plaintiffs Joseph Miller and Hurie Purdiman, Jr. are serving criminal sentences in the state of Wyoming and are incarcerated in the Wyoming State Penitentiary (WSP). Plaintiffs have been placed under the care, custody, and control of the Wyoming Department of Corrections (WDOC).
FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS 6. Defendants have issued, and they enforce, the following rule known herein as the "twenty-minute" rule. This rule affords prisoners only twenty minutes to eat their meals.
Jewish prisoners at WSP, as well as Muslim prisoners, have been adversely impacted by Defendants' "twenty-minute" rule. Both Jewish and Muslim prisoners have grieved the rule through the prison's administrative grievance process, to no avail. In response to one Jewish prisoner's grievance, Acting-Chaplain Sergeant Denise Neu stated: It is reasonable to say that each person has a right to practice a religion and a belief of their own and to follow in the ways of the religion(s) [sic] faith and beliefs as scripted by time, but regardless an inmate's chosen religious belief, an unfortunate consequence of his incarceration is that one may be required to consume their meal in a manner which may not be to their religious preference.

oreo_pegasus_output: On April 3, 2008, two Muslim prisoners at the Wyoming State Penitentiary (WSP) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Wyoming against the Warden of WSP and the Director of the Wyoming Department of Corrections (WDOC) alleging that the "twenty-minute" rule violated their religious rights under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 2000 (RLUIPA) and the Fourteenth Amendment. The plaintiffs sought preliminary injunctive relief. The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and granted their motion for a preliminary injunction. The case continues.
pegasus_output: Two Muslim prisoners filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Wyoming, seeking relief under the First Amendment and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act of 2000 (RLUIPA) against the Wyoming Department of Corrections (WDOC) and the Wyoming State Penitentiary (WSP) for violating their religious rights by requiring them to eat their meals within twenty minutes after delivery by guards. The court granted summary judgment to the WDOC on the RLUIPA claim, but remanded the case to the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings.

gold: Two non-profit organizations, the Colorado Criminal Defense Bar and the Colorado Criminal Justice Reform Coalition brought this lawsuit under 28 U.S.C. § 2201(a) against Colorado on December 2, 2010 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado. The plaintiffs, represented by pro bono private counsel, sought a declaratory judgment that a Colorado statute was unconstitutional, violating the Sixth Amendment and Fourteenth Amendments by deferring the appointment of counsel to indigent defendants until after the prosecuting attorney has spoken with the defendant. This case was voluntarily dismissed after the Colorado legislature passed a new statute that removed the requirement and subsequently allocated significant new funding to provide attorneys at initial appearances.

oreo_pegasus_output: The Colorado Criminal Justice Reform Coalition and Colorado Criminal Defense Bar filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado on May 30, 2013 against the Denver District Attorney's office and the Denver County Sheriff's Office. The plaintiffs allege that the defendants' practice of refusing to accept plea deals for indigent defendants violates the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution. The case is closed.
pegasus_output: The Colorado Criminal Justice Reform Coalition filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado on July 7, 2011 against the Governor of the State of Colorado, the Attorney General of Colorado and the District Attorney of Colorado. The plaintiffs alleged that Colorado Rev Stat.  16-7-301(4) was unconstitutional. On May 30, 2013, the parties filed a joint motion to dismiss the claims with prejudice. The parties have not yet served an answer or a motion for summary judgment in this action.

gold:
Individuals who were eligible to be assigned a public defender in New Orleans, but were placed on a waiting list due to budgetary shortages, sued the city (OPD) and Louisiana state public defender's offices for violating their Constitutional rights to counsel, due process, and equal protection. They seek attorney's fees and a declaratory judgment that their rights were violated.

On June 15, 2016 the parties filed a joint motion for judgment granting final declaratory and partial injunctive relief. On October 27, 2016 the court sua sponte raised the issue of subject matter jurisdiction, giving both parties a chance to submit briefs addressing the issue. On January 31, 2017 the court (Judge James Brady) dismissed the case, citing grounds of federalism and comity. 

On September 25, 2017 plaintiffs appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. On October 4, 2018 the Fifth Circuit dismissed the case as moot because it found that since the appeal was filed, Louisiana lawmakers had reallocated funding for appointed counsel sufficient to render the waitlists for non-capital defendants nonexistent. This case is now closed.

oreo_pegasus_output: On January 31, 2017, the ACLU of Louisiana filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana against the Chief District Defender of the Orleans Parish District Attorney's Office and the Office of Public Defender for non-capital indigent defense. The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' wait-listed status violated their Sixth Amendment right to counsel and their Fourteenth Amendment rights to equal protection and due process. The district court denied the motion for relief from judgment, citing abstention, justiciability, and federalism concerns. On February 27, 2018, the district court dismissed the case, citing no live case or controversy no jurisdiction.
pegasus_output: A class action was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana against the Louisiana Public Defender Board and the state public defender. The plaintiffs alleged that the state's chronic underfunding of its public defender system violated the Louisiana Constitution's guarantee of equal protection under the law. The district court granted a motion to dismiss, finding that it was required to abstain. The Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's dismissal of the case. In 2017, the Louisiana Legislature amended the Public Defender Act to steer $5 million more to district defenders for non-capital indigent defense. The case is now moot.

gold: A juvenile sex offender and his parents filed a lawsuit in 2013 in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama objecting to the Sheriff's Office's program of unannounced, random, and suspicion-less compliance investigations of every individual in the county who is subject to requirements of the Alabama Sex Offender Registration and Community Notification Act, Ala. Code  § 15-20A-4(12).  On February 13, 2014 the Court dismissed the case because they were informed that the parties reached a written agreement on the merits of the action and litigation costs

OF ALABAMA COMPLAINT INTRODUCTION 1. The Etowah County Sheriffs Office operates a program of unannounced, random and suspicionless compliance investigations of every individual in the county who is subject to the registration requirements of the Alabama Sex Offender Registration and Community Notification Act. Essential to the Sheriffs Office's program is that officers search the home of each registrant. Officers must also question the registrant about his or her registration information.
He resides there with his parents, John Doe and Jane Doe, and his two minor siblings. He is categorized as a "juvenile sex offender" under the Alabama Sex Offender Registration and Community Notification Act (the "Act" or "RCNA") Ala. Code § 15-20A-4(12).
Following sex offender treatment, a risk assessment, and a full hearing pursuant to Section 15-20A-26 of the Code, the Etowah County Circuit Court determined that James' risk of re-offending is low. Since April 2012, officers from the Etowah County Sheriffs Office have subjected James to random, suspicionless searches of his home without consent. The officers have also required James to submit to questioning about his registration status.
He is the father of Plaintiff James Doe. Since April 2012, officers from the Etowah County Sheriffs Office have entered his home on numerous occasions without his consent. On many of these occasions, they searched his home without his consent.
She is the mother of Plaintiff James Doe. Since April 2012, officers from the Etowah County Sheriffs Office have entered her home on numerous occasions without her consent. On many of those occasions, they searched her home without her consent.
Defendant Todd Entrekin is the duly elected Sheriff of Etowah County and serves as the county's chief law enforcement officer. He has final policymaking authority for the Etowah County Sheriffs Office. He bears direct and ultimate responsibility for the Office's policies and practices at issue in this suit.
He is sued in his individual and official capacities. Defendant Victor Payne is an officer in the Etowah County Sheriffs Office. He has conducted at least three compliance inspections at Plaintiffs' home.
He is sued in his individual capacity. Defendant James Craig Tyler is an officer in the Etowah County Sheriffs Office. He has conducted at least five compliance inspections at Plaintiffs' home.

The primary purpose of the Etowah County Sheriffs Office's program is law enforcement. The Sheriffs Office uses compliance inspections to identify and arrest individuals who are not compliant with RCNA requirements, or to make arrests for other crimes based on evidence an officer discovers during the inspection.

gold:
On June 26, 2003, two separate suits were filed against the City of Oakland and the Oakland Police Department (OPD), and related defendants, in federal court. The suits were filed in response to the OPD's actions on April 7 at a peaceful antiwar demonstration at the Port of Oakland. The Police, without giving sufficient notice to disperse and without provocation, barraged demonstrators with a variety of "less-lethal" munitions, while blocking the main exit routes. Police pursued demonstrators and others present when they attempted to disperse, while continuing to fire at them and intentionally strike them with motorcycles. On August 11, 2003, the Court ordered that the cases be officially related and heard before the same judge. One of the two cases, Local 10 ILWU v. City of Oakland, was filed as a class-action on behalf of all persons who attended the April 7 demonstration. The suit also named as plaintiffs Local 10 of the International Longshore and Warehouse Union, plus nine of its members who were "standing by" in the vicinity of the demonstration but not active participants in it. The other suit, Coles v. City of Oakland, sought relieve for several individual demonstrators who were allegedly injured by the OPD. In both cases, Plaintiffs sought compensatory, exemplary, and punitive damages, as well as to recover legal costs. They also sought declaratory judgments holding the Defendants' actions to be unlawful violations of the Plaintiffs' rights under the Constitutions of the U.S. and of California and of statutory law. They sought injunctions that among other things would prohibit the Defendants from unlawfully interference with the constitutional and statutory rights of participants in public demonstrations and protests.

On December 24, 2004, the parties entered a court-approved partial settlement addressing the Plaintiffs' claims for injunctive relief to the extent that those claims related to the Defendants' crowd control policies. Oakland adopted a new official Crowd Control Policy that forbade the police from dispersing crowds that had not behaved illegally or that did not pose a clear and present danger of imminent violence. It also forbade the indiscriminate use of less-lethal weapons directly against crowds, even when specific individuals in the group were violent. The remaining issues eventually settled, with awards of damages and attorneys' fees well in excess of $1,000,000.

oreo_pegasus_output: This case was brought by members of the International Longshore and Warehouse Union (ILWU) against the City of Oakland and the Oakland Police Department in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. The plaintiffs alleged that Oakland police officers used excessive force against them during an April 7, 2003 antiwar demonstration at the Port of Oakland. The case was consolidated with a similar case brought by the ILWU against the city of Oakland in the same court. The parties agreed to a settlement in which the city agreed to pay a total of $1 million to the plaintiffs. The settlement included a new crowd control policy. The court approved the settlement on December 28, 2004.
pegasus_output: On April 7, 2003, a group of plaintiffs, including legal observers, videographers, journalists, and dockworkers, gathered outside the gate entrances of two companies at the Port of Oakland that had economic involvement in the war in Iraq. The plaintiffs filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the City of Oakland, the Oakland Police Department, and the Oakland International Longshore and Warehouse Union (Local 10) alleging that the city's crowd control policies violated the plaintiffs' First and Fourth Amendment rights. On December 28, 2004, the court approved a partial settlement of the case. The settlement included a new Oakland Police 3 Department crowd control policy. The parties were unable to reach an agreement on the fee award. The case was closed on February 16, 2005, and the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case on July 16, 2005. On July 23, 2005, the parties reached a settlement agreement. On July 16, 2005, the court denied the parties' motions to dismiss in their entirety. On November 18, 2005, the case was dismissed.

The plaintiff filed the lawsuit on November 29, 2012 in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. The plaintiff, a demonstrator involved in the Occupy Oakland protest movement, alleged that when he was returning home from a protest, two Oakland police officers brutally beat him with clubs, sprayed painful chemicals in his face, and arrested him. The suit was filed under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, and alleged that the polices' actions violated his First Amendment right to free speech, his Fourteenth Amendment rights to equal protection and due process, and the Fourth Amendment ban on unreasonable searches and seizures. 

After two settlement conferences, the parties reached a settlement agreement which was ordered by the court on January 30, 2014. The Defendants paid $645,000 to the plaintiff to compensate his claims including attorney's fees. The case is closed.

oreo_pegasus_output: On November 29, 2012, a veteran of the war in Afghanistan filed a civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the City of Oakland and individual Oakland Police officers. The plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated his rights to freedom of speech and association, as well as his right to personal liberty and freedom of movement, under the First Amendment to the United States Constitution. On January 30, 2014, the parties agreed to settle the case for $645,000. The case was dismissed on February 6, 2014.

The plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated his rights to be free from violence and intimidation by threat of violence because of his actual or perceived race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, political affiliation and/or viewpoint, in violation of California Civil Code section 51.7. The parties reached a settlement in January 2014 and the case was dismissed on January 30, 2014.

A settlement was reached on May 11, 2020, granting plaintiffs $750,000 of attorney's fees, court fees, and class damages.

The plaintiffs alleged that the LAPD had violated their First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights under the Constitution and the California Constitution and Cal. Code  52.1 and 1798.14 by blocking their sidewalks and arresting them without probable cause during two protests in November 2014 in downtown Los Angeles. On July 29, 2015, the court entered a declaratory judgment that Defendants’ conduct detailed herein was a 23 violation of the constitutional rights and laws of the United States and 24 California of Plaintiffs and the class members. The court also entered a 10 Structural Relief Order as part of the settlement of the class action suit.

This class action lawsuit was filed in response to police actions amidst the nationwide protests that ensued following the police killing of George Floyd. The complaint, filed by seven private individuals, argues that the police use of weapons like pepper balls, pepper spray, and rubber bullets constituted violations of the protesters' First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights. The suit established two classes of plaintiffs, the Arrest Class and the Direct Force Class. 

The case is ongoing as of January 2, 2021.

oreo_pegasus_output: The plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the City of Baltimore, the Baltimore Police Department, and the Baltimore County Police Department. The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendments by detaining and/or arresting the plaintiffs in violation of their First Amendment rights. The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for injunctive relief and declaratory relief. The case is closed.
pegasus_output: On May 30, 2020, the Mayor of Denver declared an emergency and announced a curfew order for the entire city, set to begin at 8:00 p.m. that evening. The curfew was imposed in all public places within the City and County of Denver, including streets and public rights-of-way. On May 31, 2020, thousands of individuals peacefully marched and demonstrated in Denver in protest of police brutality against Black and Brown people. In response, the Denver Police Department (DPP) used tear gas, flashbang grenades, and pepper spray on peaceful protestors. On June 1, 2020, the plaintiffs filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against the DPD and the City of Denver. The plaintiffs alleged that the DPD used the use of tear gas against peaceful protestors in violation of the Fourth Amendment and the Colorado Civil Rights Act.

gold: Plaintiff brings this lawsuit under the Fourth Amendment, claiming that her rights were violated by a search of her home that was conducted without probable cause. She claims that she was prevented from entering her home while the police conducted an illegal search based on misinformation and poorly conceived police procedures. She claims that the officers during the arrest were abusive mentally and physically. On September 30, 2016, the Court granted in part and denied in part the defendants' motion to dismiss. In May 2017, the parties reached a private settlement agreement and stipulated to a dismissal of the case, which is now closed.

oreo_pegasus_output: The plaintiffs alleged that the District of Columbia Police Department violated their Fourth Amendment rights by conducting a search (or causing a search to occur) pursuant to a defective warrant. The Court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss, holding that the warrant violated plaintiffs' clearly established rights by obtaining the warrant and thereby causing the search to take place. The plaintiffs also alleged that they were prevented from reentering their home before the search began.
pegasus_output: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) and several of its officers. The plaintiff alleged that MPD officers violated his Fourth Amendment rights by arresting him for possession of marijuana and consumption of alcohol without probable cause. The case was dismissed on May 1, 2017 by Judge Randolph D. Moss.

oreo_pegasus_output: On May 25, 2020, a group of peaceful demonstrators gathered in Lafayette Square in Washington, D.C., to protest the murder of George Floyd, a father, son, brother, and African American man. On the same day, President Trump told senior advisors that they had to show that they could control the streets of Washington and the area around the White House. At the same time law enforcement officers were violently attacking demonstrators in the square. The plaintiffs filed this lawsuit against the President and Attorney General of the United States, the Chief of Staff of the U.S. Army 200 Army Pentagon, and the Secretary of the Army for violating the First Amendment and the Fourth Amendment rights of the demonstrators by ordering the use of violence against them.
pegasus_output: In May 2020, a group of civil rights activists filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against President Donald Trump, the President's Chief of Staff, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, the Chief of the D.C. Metropolitan Police Department, and several other government officials. The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants conspired to use violence against the plaintiffs and their supporters in Lafayette Square on May 31, 2020. The plaintiffs filed this suit on June 4, 2020. On August 19, 2020, the court entered a verdict against the defendants.

In 2009, patrons of an Atlanta gay bar sued the Atlanta Police Department, alleging that a raid on the bar had taken place without particularized reasonable suspicion or probable cause. The parties reached a settlement requiring the police department to reform its policies. However, after the judgment, the plaintiffs filed for sanctions twice because the police department had not implemented the policies. 

In response to a joint motion by the parties, the Court ordered the appointment of a special master on June 22, 2016 to monitor the Atlanta Police Department's compliance with court orders and assist the parties in addressing any obstacles with compliance or relevant discovery. After some time, the special master noted several disputes between the parties. The Court ordered the police department to show cause why it should not be held in contempt for violating the court order. However, as of September 2018, the parties were close to reaching a settlement agreement.

This Complaint also seeks redress for the numerous state law torts committed by individual Defendants, including false imprisonment, assault, battery, and trespass. Defendants violated the Constitution and committed said torts when, without search or arrest warrants, officers of the Atlanta Police Department (“APD”) raided the Atlanta Eagle (“the Eagle”) and Rawhide Leather (“Rawhide”) on September 10-11, 2009 (the “Raid”). During the Raid, officers of the APD detained all persons who were customers or employees at the Eagle and Rawhide (forcing most to lay flat on the ground, many to lay in spilled beer and broken glass, and restraining some with handcuffs); used excessive force, including shoving individuals to the floor and kicking others already on the floor; made threats of improper and excessive violence; made anti-gay slurs; searched all persons on the premises; seized the driver’s licenses or other ID documents of persons on the premises; and entered the names of persons on the premises into a police computer and checked their names against a police database.
(Affidavit of John Carney, 31, Attachment 4 hereto.) This action arises from a warrantless raid (the “Raid”) conducted on the night of September 10, 2009 and early morning of September 11, 1009, by the Atlanta Police Department (“APD”) on a bar called the Atlanta Eagle. Defendants have admitted that APD officers forced all 60-70 persons in the establishment to lay on the floor while they frisked them and entered all their names into a police database to search for warrants and/or criminal history.2 Plaintiffs contend, among other things, that Defendants unlawfully detained them without particularized reasonable articulable suspicion; unlawfully arrested them without probable cause; unlawfully frisked them for weapons without particularized reasonable articulable suspicion that they were armed and dangerous; unlawfully searched them without a warrant or probable cause; unlawfully searched the premises of the Atlanta Eagle, a retail store in the same building, and the home of Plaintiff Shepherd without a warrant or probable cause; and unlawfully arrested Plaintiff Shepherd in his home.
While Defendants concede that discovery in this matter has not progressed as smoothly as either side would have anticipated, this is not solely the responsibility of Defendants. This case originally was filed on November 24, 2009 alleging constitutional violations relative to an event that occurred on September 10, 2009 at the Atlanta Eagle. Service was effectuated by consent of the City on January 4, 2010 and the appropriated waivers were filed thereafter.

oreo_pegasus_output: On December 8, 2009, a group of gay bar owners and employees filed a lawsuit against the City of Atlanta in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia. The plaintiffs alleged that the City's police officers violated their civil rights when they unlawfully raided the Eagle and Rawhide bar in downtown Atlanta. The parties reached a settlement agreement in which the City agreed to implement certain reforms to deter future instances of police misconduct, including the use of anti-gay slurs, excessive force, and search and seizure. The settlement agreement was entered into on June 6, 2011, and the parties filed a motion for entry of a consent order on June 22, 2011. On July 14, 2016, the parties agreed to a joint consent order, which required the City to implement all of the reforms set forth in Exhibit A to the settlement agreement within 180 days (i.e., before June 6, 2011) of the original complaint. On June 22, 2016, the Court granted the parties' motion for consent order and for contempt of court, and on July 28, 2016, the court entered a final consent order.
pegasus_output: On September 10, 2009, a group of customers and employees of the Atlanta Eagle nightclub and Rawhide Leather filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia against the Atlanta Police Department and the City of Atlanta. The complaint alleged that the defendants conducted a warrantless raid of the Eagle on September 11, 2009 without a warrant or probable cause. In December 2010, the parties entered into a consent order (the "2010 Order"), which required the APD to undertake a number of reforms to its police force. The 2010 Order also required the City to pay the plaintiffs' attorney's fees and costs. The parties agreed to dismiss the case without prejudice.

In November 1974, several individuals and groups filed a civil rights action against Chicago's mayor and police officials, claiming that they had engaged in unlawful intelligence gathering and electronic surveillance. The plaintiffs argued that the defendants had violated the plaintiffs' constitutional rights, and they sought both damages and injunctive relief.

After the case was consolidated with a number of related cases, in August 1981, the parties entered into a consent decree settlement. The consent decree barred the City from political spying, harassment, and investigation of certain activities protected by the First Amendment. Despite the settlement, decades of litigation addressing enforcement of the decree followed.

In April 2011, the district court granted the City's motion to dismiss the case. The court's order permitted the plaintiffs to file a motion to reinstate the consent decree within 45 days if the City did not conduct an audit showing compliance with the terms of the agreement. There was no further legal action taken by either party.

Plaintiffs allege that while in the custody of the Chicago Police Department ("CPO") as post-arrest detainees, they were subjected to unlawful inten·ogation room detentions (Count I), deprived of adequate accommodations for sleep (Count II), and detained more than 48 hours before receiving a judicial hearing (Count III). oreo_pegasus_output: In 2005, a group of Chicago residents filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the Chicago Police Department. The plaintiffs alleged that the police department's practice of detaining citizens incommunicado for extended periods of time and subjecting them to torture in order to accomplish unjust ends violated their constitutional rights. The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification, and the case was transferred to the district court for further proceedings.
pegasus_output: On October 21, 2004, a class action was brought in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the Chicago Police Department ("CPO") on behalf of a group of individuals who were detained in the custody of the CPD for more than 48 hours without a judicial probable cause hearing. The plaintiffs alleged that they were subjected to unlawful intenogation room detentions (Count I), deprived of adequate accommodations for sleep (Count II), and detained in excess of 48 hours before receiving a judicial hearing (Count III) in violation of 42 U.S.C. 1983. The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to reconsider, and the parties agreed to a settlement. The final determination of the Attorneys' Fee Award will be decided by the Court, as further described in paragraph 37.

gold: On March 19, 2015 three Chicago residents filed suit against the City of Chicago and several members of the Chicago Police Department for unlawful arrest and detention and excessive use of force at the Homan Square detention facility. In May 2015 defendants filed a motion to dismiss. On March 31, 2016, the Court granted the defendants motion to dismiss; the dismissal order came 150 days later, though a written opinion and order came down on January 31, 2018. The plaintiffs appealed the Court's decision to grant the motion to dismiss to the Seventh Circuit after the written order was issued. A Seventh Circuit panel agreed with the district court on September 30, 2019; they wrote that the appeal was not filed in a timely manner, and that the underlying case was filed after the statute of limitations had passed. This decision was not appealed and the case is closed.

oreo_pegasus_output: In March 2015, three men filed a civil-rights lawsuit against the City of Chicago and Chicago Police Officers in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois. The defendants moved to dismiss the suit as untimely under the applicable two-year statute of limitations. On March 31, 2016, the district judge dismissed the suit in a minute order saying she would later file an opinion explaining her reasons. The plaintiffs then appealed. On August 17, 2018, the defendants filed their docketing statement and the parties brief the dismissal motion with the merits. The district judge issued her opinion on January 31, 2018, noting that the plaintiffs had 30 days from the date of entry of the dismissal order to appeal. On February 7, 2018, the plaintiffs filed a notice of appeal. The case is now closed.
pegasus_output: On March 19, 2015, three men filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the City of Chicago and Chicago Police Officers John Dal Ponte, Boonserm Srisutch, and Perry Nigro. The plaintiffs claimed that they were arrested without legal justification and illegally detained at a police warehouse known as Homan Square. The defendants moved to dismiss the case by minute order on March 31, 2016. The plaintiffs appealed, and the case was dismissed by the judge on January 31, 2018. On February 6, 2018, the defendants filed a notice of appeal, which expired 30 days after the judge dismissed the case. The appeal was denied on February 7, 2018.

oreo_pegasus_output: On August 25, 2020, the Kentucky Alliance Against Racial and Political Repression (KAARPR) filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky against the city of Louisville and its mayor. The plaintiffs allege that the city's police department used excessive force against peaceful protesters who were demonstrating against the death of Breonna Taylor, George Floyd, and other unarmed Black people by police. The case was brought against Louisville/Jefferson County Metro Government Defendant Greg Fischer individually and in his official capacity as Mayor of Louisville.
pegasus_output: On May 28, 2020, the ACLU of Kentucky and the NAACP of Louisville filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Kentucky against the city of Louisville and the Louisville Metro Police Department (LMPD) alleging that the LMPD used disproportionate violence to stop peaceful protesters from exercising their First and Fourth Amendment rights to peacefully assemble to protest. Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that the use of military-grade weaponry, including tear gas, batons, and pepper balls, against peaceful protesters was disproportionate to the injuries sustained by the rest of the Plaintiff Class. The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order and permanent injunction. The case is still pending in federal court.

gold: In July 1999, the U.S. Department of Justice [DOJ] initiated an investigation pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 14141 of alleged misconduct by the Canine Section of the Prince George's County Police Department [PGPD].  The investigation followed some eighteen civil rights lawsuits filed between 1993 through 1998 by individuals that alleged dog attacks by the PGPD's canine unit. Following the DOJ's investigation, DOJ, PGPD and local FOP officials met and negotiated agreements to address all of the DOJ's concerns which resulted in a Consent Decree being entered on January 22, 2004. On February 12, 2007, the Court granted the motion stating that PGPD had a) complied fully with the consent decree, and b) eliminated the last vestiges of unlawful behavior and had thus satisfied the decree.

oreo_pegasus_output: In July 1999, the U.S. Department of Justice initiated an investigation of alleged misconduct by the Canine Section of the Prince George’s County Police Department (PGPD) in the District of Maryland. The investigation focused on the use of excessive force by the PGPD’s canine unit. In October 2000, the DOJ filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the district of Maryland against the County and the PGPPD. The parties entered into a consent decree on January 22, 2004 and a memorandum of agreement (MOA) on March 11, 2007 addressing the department's use of force. The term of the agreement, as specified in paragraph 77, is three years. The three-year anniversary of the decree is March 11, 2007.
pegasus_output: On March 11, 2004, the U.S. Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland against the Prince George's County Police Department (PGPD) alleging that the PGPD's Canine Section had engaged in a pattern or practice of excessive force. The parties entered into a Consent Decree, which was entered into on March 11, 2004. The Consent Decree prohibited the use of choke holds and similar carotid holds in those instances where deadly force is authorized. The PGPD and the Office of the County Attorney proposed to insert language into its Use of Force Policies, specifically prohibiting choke holds, carotid holds, and other choke holds. The consent decree was approved by the Court and entered into three years later. The Court entered an Order of the Consent Decree on March 12, 2005. The parties have continued to monitor the Defendants’ progress towards compliance with the consent decree.

gold: This is a case brought by the U.S. Department of Justice to remedy an alleged pattern or practice of unconstitutional misconduct by the Detroit Police Department, including the excessive use of force, false arrest, improper warrantless searches and failure to protect detainees. It was filed in 2003, simultaneously with a consent decree in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan. The District Court adopted the decree, and monitoring has continued since. The consent judgments were terminated on August 25, 2014 after a finding of substantial compliance.

pegasus_output: On June 12, 2003, the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) and the City of Detroit (City) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the Detroit Police Department (DPD). The complaint alleged that the DPD had engaged in a pattern or practice of conduct resulting in unconstitutional or otherwise unlawful conditions of confinement in holding cells by officers, officers, or agents. The parties filed two Consent Judgments with the court. The consent judgments were negotiated and agreed to by the parties. The court entered two consent orders in September 2014. The consent orders were entered in September 2014 and required the DPD to revise its policies and procedures, implement corrective measures, and submit a report to the court on compliance with the consent orders. The decree also required the City to hire an independent monitor.

gold: Several Missouri residents sued the City of Ferguson, Missouri, for acts allegedly perpetrated by Ferguson police officers in the wake of the civil unrest that followed the August 2014 shooting of Michael Brown. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri granted summary judgment to the defendants on qualified immunity grounds in 2016. The plaintiffs appealed to the Eighth Circuit court of appeals, which affirmed the district court's ruling in part but reversed the grant of summary judgment on the excessive force claims of one plaintiff. A jury found in favor of the defendants at trial, and the case is closed.

The plaintiffs alleged that the police department had violated their civil rights by arresting them without probable cause, using excessive force, and failing to train, supervise, and discipline them. The defendants appealed to the Eighth Circuit. On November 14, 2018, the appeals court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants. The case is closed.

INTRODUCTION This putative class action challenges the policies and practices that the New York City Police Department ("NYPD") and the New York City Housing Authority ("NYCHA") use to enforce prohibitions against trespassing on public housing property. The lawsuit alleges that defendants' actions have resulted in a widespread pattern of unlawful stops, questioning, frisks, searches, and arrests of NYCHA residents and their invited guests.1 This is the second of three lawsuits before this Court that challenge the NYPD’s stop and frisk practices.2 Like the other two cases, and like many of its predecessors, this suit “thrusts to the fore difficult and troublesome issues regarding a sensitive area of police activity.
153, 159 (S.D.N.Y. What distinguishes this case from the other two is its focus on stop and frisk practices at public housing properties owned and operated by the New York City Housing Authority (“NYCHA”). Plaintiffs argue that the New York City Police Department (“NYPD”) uses unlawful stops, searches, and arrests to enforce the prohibition against trespassing in NYCHA buildings.2 According to plaintiffs, the NYPD’s practices violate the Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution, which guarantees “[t]he right of the people to be secure... against unreasonable searches and seizures.”
This Court has jurisdiction over this action under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331 and 1343. Venue is proper in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1391. DEFINITIONS 1.

oreo_pegasus_output: On January 28, 2010, residents of the New York City Housing Authority ("NYCHA") filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the City and the NYPD. The plaintiffs alleged that the NYPD's "vertical patrol and trespass arrest policy" had resulted in a pattern and practice of illegal stops, seizures, questioning, searches, and false airests of residents of, and authorized visitors to, NYCHA residences. The District Court dismissed the case with prejudice. The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the City agreed to revise its policy on vertical patrols, revise NYCHA's policy on trespass arrests, and to appoint a monitor to oversee reforms of the NYPD and the NYCHA. The case is now closed.
pegasus_output: On July 8, 2020, the Center for Constitutional Rights filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the New York City Housing Authority (NYHA) on behalf of NYCHA residents and their invited guests. The plaintiffs alleged that the NYCHA's use of stop and frisks resulted in a widespread pattern of unlawful stops, questioning, frisks, searches, and arrests. The NYCHA and NYCHA agreed to pay $270,000 to settle the case. The case was dismissed on July 8, 2020.

gold: Plaintiffs brought suit under 42 U.S.C sections 1981, 1983, 1985, 1986 and 1988 against the City of New York and the New York City Police Department, for wrongful death, assault, and various civil rights violations. The lawsuit arose from the shooting of Sean Bell, a 23 year-old black man who departed a strip club with two friends late one evening.  Upon getting into a car, a group of five police officers opened fire on the three men, killing Bell and severely injuring the other passengers. The parties reached a $7 million dollar settlement agreement and the suit was dismissed, with prejudice, upon the stipulation and order of Judge Roanne L. Mann (United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York).

oreo_pegasus_output: On August 8, 2007, a New York City resident filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the City, the New York Police Department, and several of its officers. The plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated his civil rights by shooting at him multiple times without reason or provocation. The court granted the defendants' motion for extension of time to respond to the suit on August 23, 2007 and the case was closed on September 19, 2007.
pegasus_output: On November 25, 2006, a New York City resident and his family filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the City, the New York Police Department, and several of its officers. The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the civil rights of the plaintiff by using excessive force when arresting him at Kalua Cabaret in Queens, New York, on November 25, 2006. The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment and granted the plaintiff's motion for a trial by jury. The case is closed.

gold: New York Attorney General Letitia James filed this lawsuit against the NYPD on behalf of New York residents on January 14, 2021. The suit alleged that the NYPD regularly falsely arrested and used excessive force against peaceful protesters during the 2020 racial justice protests in violation of the First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendments. It also alleged violations of the New York State Constitution and state law, including instances of assault, battery, and false arrest and imprisonment by NYPD officers. The suit sought declaratory and injunctive relief requiring the NYPD cease unconstitutional policing practices and change its existing policies and training practices. As of March 7, 2021, the case is ongoing before the District Court.

pegasus_output: On March 5, 2021, the New York State Attorney General's Office filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the City Of New York. The lawsuit alleged that the NYPD's use of excessive force against peaceful protesters during the 2020 Racial Justice Protests in New York City was unconstitutional and violated the First and Fourteenth Amendment rights of the protesters. The case was dismissed on March 10, 2021.

gold: Following an eight-year investigation, the United States DOJ filed a lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 14141 against the City of Warren, Ohio and its police department.  The United States alleged that the Warren Police Department had engaged in a pattern of conduct involving the use of excessive force. The parties reached a quick, court-approved settlement that required the WPD to adopt new protocols and procedures. The court terminated the decree in August 2019 after the U.S. determined that the WPD fully complied with the settlement.

oreo_pegasus_output: On January 13, 2012, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio against the City of Warren, Ohio and the Warren Police Department (WPD) alleging that the WPD engaged in a pattern or practice of use of excessive force in violation of the Fourth Amendment by subjecting individuals to excessive force. The case was settled on January 13, 2012 with a consent decree that required WPD to revise its policies and procedures in line with national policing standards. The consent decree was entered into by the Judge overseeing the case. The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which WPD agreed to: (a) provide its officers with 40-hour training blocks regarding all 47 provisions for two consecutive years; (b) provide the DOJ with more data for assessing the objective reasonableness of the uses of force; (c) require WPD officers to spend two to three hours every six months qualifying with firearms.
pegasus_output: In December 2004, the U.S. Department of Justice's Civil Rights Division filed this lawsuit against the City of Warren, Ohio, alleging that the Warren Police Department (WPD) engaged in unconstitutional or unlawful policing through the use of ex cessiv e force. The complaint alleged that the WPD engaged in a pattern or practice of violating the civil rights of African-American and Hispanic residents of the city of Warren by using excessive and unnecessary force against them. On January 13, 2012, the Justice Department announced that it had resolved its inv estigation and entered into a settlement agreement with the city. The settlement agreement was entered into by Judge Benita Y. Pearson of the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio. The case was dismissed on February 6, 2012.

pegasus_output: On June 5, 2020, a group of African-American protestors in Columbus, Ohio, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio against the City of Columbus alleging that the indefinite, city-wide curfew was unconstitutional. The plaintiffs alleged that the use of tear-gas and smoke bombs against the protestors was unlawful and that the plaintiffs were injured and unable to work or care for themselves as a result of their injuries. gold:
This class-action lawsuit was filed on June 28, 2020 in response to Portland Police Bureau's allegedly illegal tactics in quelling the protests in that city after the police killing of George Floyd in May of 2020. The plaintiffs, who were members of media and legal observers of the protests, argued that their First Amendment and Fourth Amendment rights were violated by the PPB's use of pepper spray and rubber bullets, among other weapons. They sought injunctive, declaratory, and monetary relief. 

The court granted a TRO against the city, prohibiting the police from arresting or seizing the equipment of reporters or legal observers of the protests. The court later granted a preliminary injunction against the city.  

By July 16, President Trump had sent in federal officers from the DHS and USMS as reinforcement. The plaintiffs added those two organizations as defendants and filed a motion for a TRO and preliminary injunction. 

The motion for temporary restraining order and the motion for preliminary injunction were both granted. These decisions were appealed to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, which has yet to rule on them. However, on October 9, the Ninth Circut declined to stay the preliminary injunction pending appeal. The federal defendants filed a motion to dismiss, which remains pending.

The case is ongoing as of December 31, 2020.

This case seeks to stop the Portland police1 from assaulting news reporters, photographers, legal observers, and other neutrals who are documenting the police’s violent response to protests over the murder of George Floyd. oreo_pegasus_output: On June 28, 2020, a group of Portland journalists and legal observers filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon against the City of Portland, the Portland Police Bureau, and federal agents. The plaintiffs alleged that they were assaulted by federal agents who used tear gas, pepper spray, and batons to disperse protesters. The district court granted a temporary restraining order (TRO) and preliminary injunction against the federal agents on July 2, 2020. On July 16, the district court entered a TRO that was largely identical to the TRO. The parties agreed to a preliminary injunction on July 16, 2020.
pegasus_output: On July 1, 2020, Portland newspapers filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon against the City of Portland, the U,S. Department of Homeland Security, and the U-S. Marshals Service. The plaintiffs alleged that the Portland Police Department's use of tear gas and rubber bullets against protesters during protests over the murder of George Floyd violated the First Amendment rights of journalists and other neutrals. On July 29, 2020, the parties reached an agreement to resolve the case. The parties agreed that the police department would not use tear gas, rubber bullets, or any other form of physical force against protesters. The case was dismissed on July 23, 2020.

gold: Class action filed on March 4, 2003 alleging that the City of Philadelphia engaged in a practice of arresting indigent alleged traffic code violators and subjecting them to incarceration until substantial fines were paid on the basis of Philadelphia Traffic Court proceedings conducted without the assistance of counsel, notice of specific charges, opportunity to prepare a defense, cross-examine witnesses, or offer evidence on their own behalf. The District Court ( Judge Timothy J. Savage) enjoined the City of Philadelphia from incarcerating alleged traffic code violators without giving them notice of their right to counsel and appeal to the Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas. Subsequently the parties settled plaintiffs' claims, stipulating to class certification.

At the Traffic Court proceedings, members of the Plaintiff Class were not advised of the specific charges against them and were not afforded the opportunity to prepare a defense, to confront and cross-examine the witnesses against them and to present evidence on their own behalf. Members of the Plaintiff Class were sentenced to periods of incarceration in the Philadelphia County Prison System. The Traffic Court judges further ordered that members of the Plaintiff Class were to be held in the Philadelphia County Prison System until dates certain or until substantial amounts of money were paid to secure their release.
As members ofthe PlaintiffClass were financially unable to make the required payments, they were held in the Philadelphia County Prison System for extended periods of time. It was the policy and practice ofDefendants City of Philadelphia, Philadelphia Traffic Court, Kelly and Perri to release from custody individuals with the financial means to pay a portion of the outstanding fines and costs that accrued in connection with alleged Motor Vehicle Code violations.

oreo_pegasus_output: The Plaintiff Class consists of individuals who have been and will be arrested for alleged Motor Vehicle Code violations and subjected to periods of incarceration as a result of Philadelphia Traffic Court proceedings conducted without the assistance of counsel, notice of the specific charges against them, the opportunity to prepare a defense, to confront and cross-examine the witnesses against them and to offer evidence on their own behalf. The Traffic Court judges further ordered that members of the Plaintiff Class were to be held in the Philadelphia County Prison System until dates certain or until substantial amounts of money were paid to secure their release.
pegasus_output: In March 2003, a class action lawsuit was brought in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania against the City of Philadelphia, the Philadelphia Traffic Court, and the Philadelphia County Prison System. The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' practice of releasing from custody individuals with the financial means to pay a portion of the outstanding fines and costs accrued in connection with alleged Motor Vehicle Code violations violated their civil rights. The parties entered into a settlement agreement on July 10, 2003 and the case was dismissed on July 8, 2003.

oreo_pegasus_output: In 1967, a group of African-American teachers in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania against the City of Pittsburgh, its mayor, and other city and police officials. The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their First Amendment rights to freedom of speech and assembly, their Fourth Amendment rights, and their Fourteenth Amendment rights not to be subject to official policies which violate their constitutional rights. The district court dismissed the plaintiffs' claims on the grounds that the plaintiffs had no standing to sue.
pegasus_output: On June 1, 2020, a group of protesters gathered in the East Liberty neighborhood of the City of Pittsburgh to protest police violence against peaceful protesters. The protesters alleged that police officers used chemical gas, rubber bullets and other projectiles, pepper spray, flashbang grenades and other riot control agents indiscriminately against everyone present, including peaceful protesters and nonviolent bystanders. The plaintiffs filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania against the city of Pittsburgh, the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police, and the city's Department of Public Safety. The class action was granted by the district court under the provisions of Rule 23(b)(2), which reads: "An action may be maintained as a classaction if the prerequisites of subdivision (a) are satisfied, and in addition:... gold: Plaintiffs, individual Hispanic members of a high school soccer team, sued police officers and the City of Coventry based on police search of the team after an away soccer game. Plaintiffs alleged Fourth Amendment and Equal Protection claims in violation of  42 U.S.C. § 1983 as well as a number of analogous state law claims. On September 9, 2009, the district court granted summary judgment for defendants on all of plaintiffs' claims, and on April 1, 2011, the First Circuit affirmed.

oreo_pegasus_output: On September 28, 2006, the Central Falls High School soccer team played an away game Coventry High School. Before the game began, five or six Central Falls players used the bathrooms located inside the Coventry boys locker room. The defendants escorted the bus out of town in their cruisers. After the game was over, the players filed suit in April 2008 against the Town of Coventry and several individual Coventry police officers under 42 U.S.C.  1983 and Rhode Island state law. The district court granted summary judgment for the defendants on all counts, holding that the officers were entitled to qualified immunity with respect to the Fourth Amendment and state privacy claims because it was not unreasonable for the officers to believe that Coach Marchand had power to consent to the search, and (2) coercion did not vitiate Marchand's consent. The Court did not address Fourth Amendment searches.
pegasus_output: On September 28, 2006, the Central Falls High School soccer team filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island against the Town of Coventry and its police officers. The plaintiffs alleged that the Coventry police violated their rights to due process, equal protection, and freedom from unreasonable search and seizure. The District Court granted summary judgment to the Coventry defendants on all counts, finding that the officers were entitled to qualified immunity with respect to the claims for the violations of their players rights under the Fourth Amendment, and also under R.I.G.L. As its basis, the District Court ruled that Coach Marchand had given an uncoerced consent to the search.

gold: Four residents of Memphis and the ACLU-TN sought enforcement of the Kendrick Decree against the City of Memphis. They claimed the City and its police force collected information in violation of the First Amendment right to peacefully protest. The four original plaintiffs were dismissed for lack of standing, but the ACLU-TN ultimately received court enforcement of the Decree against the City. A federal court found that the City violated its obligations under the consent decree after a 2018 trial and later, in 2020, rejected the City's request for the decree to be modified. The decree remains in effect while the city appeals that decision.

oreo_pegasus_output: The American Civil Liberties Union of Tennessee (ACLU-TN) sued the City of Memphis and the Memphis Police Department (MPD) in the United States District Court for the Western District of Tennessee for violating the First Amendment rights of Memphis residents by collecting personal information about them for the purpose of First Amendment-related intelligence in the course of a lawful investigation of criminal conduct. On December 20, 2018, the Court granted the City's motion to stay and/or modify the Kendrick Consent Decree. The parties also filed a joint motion to vacate and Vacate the consent decree. The Court denied the motion, and the parties will file an amended Judgment and Order in both cases.
pegasus_output: On September 14, 1978, the ACLU of Tennessee, Inc. (ACLU-TN) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee against the City of Memphis, the Mayor, and the Chief of Intelligence Section of the Memphis Police Department, individually and in their official capacities. The complaint alleged that the defendants' surveillance of political groups and actions that went beyond surveillance alone violated the First Amendment rights of the plaintiffs. The parties entered into a consent decree (ECF No. 2:76-cv-00449) in which the defendants agreed to refrain from targeting political groups, collect information unrelated to a lawful criminal investigation, consult with the FBI regarding national social media policies, and create social media accounts for the purpose of First Amendment-related intelligence. On March 3, 2017, the ACLU-TN filed an intervening complaint, which challenged the City's compliance with the Consent Decree. The Court found the City in contempt of the Decree in several respects and issued sanctions, including the appointment of an independent monitor to oversee the City’s compliance. The case is closed.

gold: In March 2004, the Department of Justice (DOJ) opened an investigation into the Virgin Islands Police Department's (VIPD) practices regarding use of excessive force, and on December 23, 2008, filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands. On March 24, 2009, the parties signed a consent decree, detailing specific actions to be taken by VIPD. Enforcement of the consent decree is in progress.

The Consent decree set forth various reforms to be implemented by the Government of the Virgin Islands and the Virgin Islands Police Department (collectively, the “Virgin Islands”) in order to correct an alleged systematic violation of constitutional rights through excessive force.
Introduction This is the Third Quarterly Report of 2013 from the Office of the Independent Monitor (the “OIM” or the “Monitor”) for the United States Virgin Islands Police Department (the “VIPD” or the “Department”), covering the quarter ending on September 30, 2013. The OIM was established in January 2010 to monitor compliance by the United States Virgin Islands (the “Territory”) and the VIPD with the Consent Decree entered by the United States District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands (the “Court”) on March 23, 2009. The Monitor is required by the Consent Decree to “issue quarterly written, public reports detailing the Territory‟s compliance with and implementation of each substantive provision” of the Consent Decree.2 The Consent Decree reflects the agreement between the Territory, the VIPD, and the United States Department of Justice (the “DOJ”) (collectively, the “Parties”) to resolve a lawsuit brought by the United States alleging that the Territory and the VIPD violated 42 U.S.C. § 14141 by engaging “in a pattern or practice of excessive force by Officers of the Virgin Islands Police Department and by the failure to adequately train, supervise, investigate, and discipline Officers.


In addition, there were frequent communications and updates, telephonically and electronically, between the VIPD and the Police Practices Experts during the Fourth Quarter of 2013, as well as periodic telephone conferences among the VIPD, the Virgin Islands Attorney General’s Office (the “VIAG”), the Office of the Governor, the United States Department of Justice (the “DOJ”), the Police Practices Experts, and the Monitor to discuss the VIPD’s efforts towards substantial compliance with the Consent Decree. On November 18, 2013 (the “November 18 Hearing”), the United States District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands (the “Court”) held a full day hearing to review a joint motion filed by the Parties to extend the Consent Decree’s October 31, 2013 substantial compliance deadline for another two years (the “Joint Motion”). As previously reported, the original deadline for substantial compliance was March 23, 2012, to be followed by two consecutive years of compliance, at which time the Consent Decree would terminate.
Also, during this reporting period training was conducted in Crisis Intervention May 13-14 and 15-16, 2014 in the St. Thomas/St. John District and May 19-20, 2014 and May 21-22, 2014 in the St. Croix District. pegasus_output: On March 23, 2009, the U.S. District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands (the 'Court') entered a Consent Decree between the Virgin Island Police Department ('VIPD') and the Department of Justice ('DOJ') to correct an alleged systematic violation of constitutional rights through excessive force. The Consent Decree required the VIPD to implement a series of reforms, including training, supervision, investigation, and discipline measures. The parties agreed to a two-year extension of the Consent Decree's deadline for substantial compliance, which was March 23, 2012, to be followed by two consecutive years of compliance, at which time the consent decree would terminate. The third quarterly report of the Office of the Independent Monitor ('OIM' or the 'Monitor') for the United States Virgin Islands Police Department covered the quarter ending on September 30, 2013. The Monitor is required to issue quarterly written, public reports detailing the Territory's compliance with and implementation of each substantive provision.

The court dismissed the case in October 2017, holding that there was no constitutional right to self-defense. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed the holding.

pegasus_output: In July 2012, a group of Seattle police officers filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the City of Seattle and the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) alleging that the city's use-of-force policy violated the Second Amendment right of police officers to use firearms for the core lawful purpose of self-defense. The district court dismissed the case with prejudice because the case was not supported by the Constitution or case law. The case was remanded to the district court for further proceedings on the constitutionality of the policy.

Both the Ninth Circuit and the United States Supreme Court denied motions for injunction pending the Ninth Circuit’s appeal; as of August 6, 2020, the appeal is pending in the Ninth Circuit.

gold: On Mar. 16, 2017, the New York Times and one of its reporters sued DOJ under FOIA seeking records on DOJ's review of the legality of Trump's proposed Executive Orders and other matters related to anti-nepotism laws and the Emoluments Clause. The plaintiffs dismissed the case after the government released documents in response to their request.

oreo_pegasus_output: On January 28, 2017, The New York Times Company and The Washington Post Company filed a FOIA request with the Department of Justice (DOJ) seeking records related to the Office of Legal Counsel (OLC) and the early days of the Trump administration. On February 27, 2017, Plaintiffs filed the complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York. The complaint alleged that the DOJ had failed to respond to the request within 20 business days, as required under FOIA, and that Plaintiffs had exhausted their administrative remedies under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) by failing to receive the requested records. On March 6, 2018, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, and the case is closed.

On November 15, 2017, the Government provided two further responses to Plaintiffs’ requests, and also provided the relevant FOIA responses made in other litigations. On March 16, 2018, the parties reached additional agreements and jointly and respectfully requested the Court’s endorsement of the following: (1) By March 5, 2018, the Government will provide Plaintiffs with an index of all documents in the Government’s production set (defined as responsive documents located via reasonable searches, subject to production and processing agreements previously reached by the parties) that have not yet been processed for release by the Government. (2) The Government will release the remaining 326 pages in full pursuant to Exemption Five, and in part to Exemption Six.

After the Second Circuit affirmed the district court's granting summary judgment to the plaintiffs, the U.S. Supreme Court vacated the opinion and directed the Second Circuit to dismiss the case as moot because there was a change in presidential administrations due to the 2020 election.

oreo_pegasus_output: The Knight First Amendment Institute at Columbia University sued President Donald Trump in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York. The plaintiffs alleged that Trump violated the First Amendment by blocking them from accessing the comment threads on his @POTUS and @WhiteHouse Twitter accounts. The case was remanded to the Second Circuit with instructions to dismiss the case as moot. The Second Circuit held that the comments were a public forum and that the President's control of the accounts belonged to the government.
pegasus_output: The Knight First Amendment Institute at Columbia University sued President Donald Trump and certain White House officials in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York. The plaintiffs claimed that the President's use of his personal Twitter account, @realDonaldTrump, to make official statements on a wide variety of subjects, many of great national importance, violated their First Amendment rights. The district court found that Mr. Trump's blocking of the plaintiffs' access to his account was unconstitutional viewpoint discrimination. On July 9, 2019, the Second Circuit affirmed the district court's judgment. The case is now moot.

gold: This is a case about former President Donald Trump’s dispute with Congressional subpoenas requesting personal tax and financial documents. The complaint alleged that the Congressional subpoenas were issued to harass the President and lacked a legitimate legislative purpose. The case was eventually consolidated with Trump v. Mazars, LLP, which was heard by the Supreme Court in July 2020 and later remanded for further proceedings.

gold: A group of Orthodox Jewish synagogues brought this lawsuit against the Governor of New York on October 8, 2020, alleging that the governor's restrictions on gatherings in light of surges in COVID-19 cases violated the Free Exercise Clause. After the district court denied plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, they appealed to the Second Circuit and the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court granted the injunction in part to block the enforcement of the executive order's attendance caps pending the outcome of the appeal in the Second Circuit. The case is ongoing.

Plaintiffs are sincere practitioners of Judaism who believe that attending religious services at the synagogue, especially on Jewish holidays, is a critical and necessary component of their religious practices and beliefs. EO 202.68’s restrictions make it impossible for Plaintiffs and their congregants and others to conduct services on Jewish holidays observed on October 9, 10, and 11, 2020, thereby infringing upon Plaintiffs’ ability to comply with religious dictates.

oreo_pegasus_output: On March 23, 2020, a group of Orthodox Jewish organizations, synagogues, and rabbis filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against New York Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn. The plaintiffs alleged that the Governor's new gathering restrictions violated their First Amendment rights by limiting attendance at houses of worship that fall within red, orange, and yellow zones, particularly as Orthodox Jewish congregants get ready to celebrate three upcoming Jewish holidays on October 9, 10, and 11 Compl. The district court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction against the enforcement of the executive order, and the parties moved for emergency injunctions pending appeal and to expedite their appeals. The case will be heard in tandem with the motion seeking similar relief filed in The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Brooklyn v. Gov. Cuomo on October 27, 2020.
pegasus_output: In October 2020, a group of Orthodox Jewish Congregations filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, and the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. The plaintiffs alleged that EO 202.68 infringed on their First Amendment rights by restricting their ability to conduct religious services on Jewish holidays. The district court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction pending the outcome of their appeal of the district court's final judgment. The Supreme Court and the Ninth Circuit denied their requests for injunctive relief. The case is now closed.
