oreo_pegasus_output: The City of Mount Vernon and the City of Burlington were sued in 2011 by a group of indigent defendants who claimed that the defendants' contract with Sybrandy and Witt allowed each attorney to handle up to 13 l,200 cases per year even though such a caseload is three times the maximum allowable 14 amoWtt for a full-time public defender pursuant to standards established by the Washington 15 State Bar Association. The plaintiffs alleged that defendants had failed to provide adequate funding for their public defense system. The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for injunctive relief, requiring the defendants to hire more public defenders and pay more for their services.
pegasus_output: The City of Mount Vernon and the City of Burlington were sued in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington for violating the Sixth Amendment by failing to protect indigent persons and secure their constitutional rights. The complaint alleged that the defendants failed to take reasonable steps to protect the defendants' constitutional rights and to provide them with the assistance of counsel for their defense. The parties reached an agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the defendants $121,750/year for combined services, or $117,400/year if arraignment is necessary. The case was dismissed on June 18, 2013 by the Court.

On November 13, 2018, CNN and CNN’s chief White House correspondent Jim Acosta sued President Trump and several senior members of his administration for violating his First and Fifth Amendment rights by revoking his White House press credentials. under The plaintiffs sued under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Declaratory Judgments Act, arguing that defendants violated the Constitution and APA when they revoked Acosta’s White House press credentials. 

On November 13, 2018, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, requesting that the court require the defendants to restore Acosta’s White House press credentials. On November 16, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion. 

Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case on November 19, 2018 after the Trump administration returned Acosta's White House press credentials to him. The case is now closed.

oreo_pegasus_output: CNN and two of its journalists filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against President Donald Trump, the White House, and John F. Kelly, the Chief of Staff to the President. The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their First and Fifth Amendment rights by revoking the press credentials of CNN's chief White House correspondent, Acosta. The defendants claimed that they revoked Acosta's credentials because he "plac[ed] his hands" on an intern. The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and granted their motion for a permanent injunction.
pegasus_output: On November 13, 2018, CNN's chief White House correspondent, Jim Acosta, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against President Donald J. Trump and the United States Secret Service. The complaint alleged that the President's decision to revoke Acosta's White House press credentials violated his First and Fifth Amendment rights. On November 15, 2018, Judge Timothy J. Kelly granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order and permanent restraining order. The case was closed on November 18, 2018.

oreo_pegasus_output: On June 26, 2020, a group of Orthodox Jewish and Catholic religious leaders filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York against New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio. The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated their First Amendment rights by imposing restrictions on their religious services during Sabbath services. The court granted the plaintiffs' request for a temporary restraining order (with notice) in time for Sabbath services on Friday, June 12 (at sundown) and Sunday Masses on June 14. The case is ongoing.

The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. The case is ongoing.

gold: The NAACP and Detroit students and parents sued the Detroit school board and other state defendants in federal court, alleging unconstitutional segregation in Detroit's schools. The district court found that Detroit's schools were illegally segregated, in part because of decisions made by the school board to create and maintain and segregated system. The district court found that a Detroit-only remedy would be insufficient, and ordered a busing plan that would have affected students in city schools and 53 largely white suburban school districts, but the Supreme Court rejected this plan and a Detroit-only remedy was implemented.

pegasus_output: On December 3, 1970, a class of Detroit school children filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the Detroit Board of Education, the State of Michigan, and the Detroit Federation of Teachers. The district court found that the Detroit School District was segregated on the basis of race and violated the Fourteenth Amendment rights of the children. The case was remanded to the district court for a hearing on its merits. The parties reached an agreement in June 1981 to desegregate the Detroit Public Schools and the parties agreed on the amount which the state defendants would contribute to the cost of providing for the educational remedies. The Supreme Court granted certiorari and reversed in part.
